items.content_html:
Summary

Clarify that the retry field changes the browser’s reconnection delay.

Motivation

I was reading this documentation and was confused by the definition for retry because it says “attempting to send the event”, but the browser doesn’t send events and the server normally doesn’t care about the event it sends.

Supporting details

I found a clearer explaination of the behavior of retry on: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/server-sent-events.html#processField

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Clarify event stream “retry” field

items.content_html:
This PR converts the docs under https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Add-ons to Markdown.

Prep: #9842.

Conversion report summary

All unhandled elements

  • div.hidden (369)
  • td (74)
  • table.fullwidth-table.standard-table (66)
  • tr (31)
  • kbd (26)
  • table.standard-table (8)
  • th (4)
  • table (3)
  • td[colSpan="2"] (2)
  • td[rowSpan="2"] (1)

Full conversion report

https://gist.github.com/wbamberg/e891ad5506798c8b1d9e3b7a897f8033

Some notes on unconverted elements:

  • The hidden <div> elements are all the copyright notices, which as discussed in #9847 is seemed best to leave that way.
  • We have not converted any tables, as discussed in #9966
  • As in other cases we have left <kbd> unconverted.
items.title: [Markdown][Add-ons] Convert Add-ons docs to Markdown - DO NOT SQUASH MERGE

items.content_html:
Fixes #10054

animations to look smooth and feel responsive, the content repaints should occur at 60 frames per second (60fps), which is once every 16.7ms. The 16.7 milliseconds includes scripting, reflow, and repaint.

Ref - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Performance/How_long_is_too_long

Summary

Motivation

Supporting details

items.content_html:
Summary

According to ECMAScript Documentation, the radix is converted using the internal method ToInt32 which applies modulo to any number greater than 2 ** 32.

Motivation

Readers of this documentation may find it surprising if they try something like parseInt("3ab", 4294967312) and it returns a valid integer, meanwhile according to this documentation, every radix greater than 32 return NaN. I believe that detail is important for the reader of this documentation to know

Supporting details

https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-parseint-string-radix

Related issues

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Added more information to parseInt documentation

    • Replace it using "Storing Response", "Reusing Response" explicitly
    • adding Vocabulary section
  • rewriting each directives align with Vocabulary
  • adding newly defined must-understand in the same manner
  • rewriting Examples with a same manner
    • rename it use cases
    • adding 'clearing already stored cache' as @mnot mentions
  • Totally rewrite

items.content_html:
Fixes #9171

Safari has a complicated rollout story for WebM. The summary is:

  • Safari 12.1: (macOS, iOS) initial support for VP8 in WebM for WebRTC only
  • Safari 14: (macOS, iOS) supports VP9 in WebM for WebRTC.
  • Safari 14: (macOS) Supports VP9 in MSE from MacOS 11.3.
  • Safari 14.1: (macOS) supports WebM files containing VP8 or VP9 video tracks and Vorbis audio tracks.
  • Safari 15: (macOS) supports VP9 in WebM in MSE and the Opus audio codec in WebM.

From Safari 14.1 it looks like you can use WebMs mandated/free codecs everywhere - WebRTC, MSE, in video tags ON macOS 11.3 and later. On iOS support is still VP9 and Opus for audio. The docs indicate Vorbis might also be supported, but no idea when that came in.

Anyway, this updates the containers and video codecs with the information above. Because I also played with the layout, I will add a note at the "important" bits.

I'm also coming to the conclusion that it would be good to get this all in BCD.

@jwatt FYI, finally got to this.
items.title: Webm support safari
